title: Tuesday, 6th December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Oh, it's you again. Hello. Welcome to Markets Live.

BE11:04am

Today's image ......... It's my phone. This morning.

BE11:04am

11:04 am
BE11:05am

Excellent timing with that Twitter promotion, IG.

IG Group Holdings PLC (IGG:LSE): Last: 538.63, down 248.37 (-31.56%), High: 669.50, Low: 526.00, Volume: 6.18m
BE11:06am

By now you've probably read the FCA's CP 16/40 “Enhancing conduct of business rules for firms providing contract for difference products to retail clients”

11:06 am
BE11:06am

If you haven't, here are the highlights.

BE11:06am

The FCA suggests retail investors are limited to 25x leverage in their first 1 2 months, and 50x leverage thereafter.

BE11:06am

FCA also suggest the mandatory introduction of disclosures on the ratio of winning/losing positions.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

And estimates that 82% of clients lose money on these products.

BE11:07am

(Which is lower than I would have guessed, as it happens.)

BE11:08am

Also proposes bringing in binaries to its regulatory purview.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

(At the moment they're regulated by the Gambling Commission.)

BE11:09am

Binaries "do not appear to meet a genuine investment need", says the FCA, with admirable understatement.

BE11:09am

Consultation until 7 March 2017, Policy statement Spring 2017.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

So, in terms of the damage .....

CMC Markets PLC (CMCX:LSE): Last: 129.38, down 55.02 (-29.84%), High: 142.20, Low: 125.60, Volume: 1.80m
BE11:10am

240p float in February, of course.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

In which Peter Crudas and Goldman took about £200m off the table ....

BE11:11am

Goldman -- still a 5% shareholder, if I'm not mistaken -- says .....

BE11:11am

The implications for CMC and other CFD/spread-betting companies is potentially highly negative. We believe leverage on some CMC products can be as high as 500x, while binary products were an area of growth for CMC.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

FIVE HUNDRED TIMES!

BE11:11am

That said, some aspects of the proposals are potentially positive for CMC. The FCA also plans to strengthen protections against passporting into the UK by firms that would not meet UK standards. There are around 1 30 firms registered to provide cross-border services in the UK under a MiFID passport. The FCA also proposes limitations on incentives to open new accounts. Both proposals are likely to favour CMC Markets.

BE11:12am

We are Neutral rated on CMC Markets ....

11:12 am
BE11:12am

... bet you are. You only lead the float of the thing, and slotted half your stake at a price approximately twice what it is this morning ....

BE11:13am

.... last close 1 84p. Our 1 2-month price target of 255p is derived by applying a target P/E multiple of 1 5.5x (5-year average P/E of peers) to calendar 201 7E EPS. Key risks include exposure to market and customercredit risks, and more onerous regulation. CMC’s founder and CEO also owns c.60% of the group’s equity, presenting potential ‘key man’ risk. A fall in volatility may also
adversely affect trading volumes on CMC’s platform.

BE11:13am

RBC was also a bookrunner on the CMC float, I think.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

This is negative – period - and CMC Markets and IG Group – the two that operate to the highest standards in the industry in our opinion – are collateral damage. We do not believe that they are the intended targets, but will be negatively impacted nonetheless. While the quantum of the impact is very difficult to determine, we believe the companies will experience share price reactions as a result of souring sentiment, derating and a likely negative impact to forecasted growth. According to their last published financial statements, CMC Markets earns just under 40% of its revenue in the UK, while IG Group earns just over 50% of its revenue in the UK. We believe that it is possible and likely that other countries within the EU follow suit.

BE11:14am

And Citi wasn't.

BE11:14am

This has taken us by surprise – we were not expecting the FCA to propose leverage limits.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Seriously, what?

BE11:14am

I mean, regulatory risks were in big letters on page 7 of CMC's flotation prospectus

BE11:14am

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And on page 12

BE11:14am

BE11:14am

And on nearly all of page 22

11:14 am
BE11:15am

BE11:15am

I mean .... Back to Citi, though.

BE11:15am

Also the language around binary bets: “pose investor protection risks and question whether these meet a genuine investment need” and finding that “82% of clients lose money on CFD products” and “serious concerns that an increasing number of retail clients are trading in CFD products without an adequate understanding of the risks involved” may pose concerns for the industry growth outlook, in our view.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

They estimate a 25% hit to trading in jurisdictions to add leverage limits, such as Japan.

BE11:17am

"Trading" there means client activity -- and remember that spread betters make nearly all their money from quite a small group of clients.

BE11:18am

There's the ones who play once, get stopped out and never play again ... then there are the ones that play habitually and have enough wealth to keep burning.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Premiership footballers who think horses are too plebian .... offspring of the idle rich who want to pretend they're in Wolf Of Wall Street .... those types.

BE11:19am

Back to Citi.

BE11:19am

We note that IG Group generated approximately £45-£50m (10% group) revenue from Binary Options in FY May 2016, of which we estimate around 30% comes from the UK. We had been concerned that bad behavior by some ‘toxic’ firms outside the UK would lead to reputational taint – but the comments from the FCA today seem to suggest the entire product could no longer be viable.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

We further note that when Japan introduced leverage limits IG Group saw a significant fall in revenues from that region: from £28m FY09 to £21m FY10 (limit of 50x set in 2009) and to £16m FY12 (limit of 25x set in August 2011); although these falls also partly attributable to lower FX volatility. UK = 50% group revenue in FY May 16.
Citi View.
IG has been focused on new client growth in recent periods, with improved digital marketing techniques and new Limited Risk Accounts offering new channels for growth. We believe LRAs would address many of the FCA’s concerns. However, we do see the introduction of leverage limits as likely a dampener on customer trading levels and so group revenues.

BE11:22am

@Dunoon ... up to a point. .....

BE11:22am

Here's the bit of the CMC prospectus on client cash concentration.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

BE11:24am

... all bookies rely on keeping their biggest spenders sweet. Big bookies are no different.

BE11:25am

Oh, and just to round up on prices ....

11:24 am
Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 369.25, down 141.75 (-27.74%), High: 407.75, Low: 311.00, Volume: 4.85m
BE11:25am

You'll remember Cyprus doing something very similar to the FCA last week.

BE11:26am

https://ftalphavil...alcon&desktop=true

11:26 am
undefined
BE11:27am

FTSE's flat, so let's not waste time there.

BE11:28am

This Drax deal mentioned on the right already.

11:27 am
Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 328.50, up 50.9 (+18.34%), High: 329.00, Low: 273.10, Volume: 2.41m
BE11:28am

Pretty good reaction to a profit warning

BE11:29am

And also the slightly surprising news that the company isn't the one investors bought any more.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

So, it's not a coal-fired power station trying to shift into biomass, depending on legal and political vagaries .....

BE11:30am

It's now a retail energy company.

BE11:30am

Buying Opus Energy for £340m

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Along with four OCGT development projects

BE11:31am

Here's Jefferies to explain where we are.

BE11:31am

. In light of the biomass conversions nearing completion, Drax has announced a strategy update focused on improving the diversification and security of its earnings. Drax is set to acquire Opus Energy and the sites of four potential OCGT projects. Following these acquisitions and approval of the CfD, Drax's earnings are set to be largely contracted and visible.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Opus Energy acquisition. Drax is set to acquire Opus Energy for £340m, representing a 10x EV/EBITDA multiple. Opus Energy is an energy supplier in the SME market with c.129,000 customers (265k meters) and an 8% market share. When combined with current retail business Haven, today's acquisition will create the fifth largest supplier in the non-domestic market.

BE11:32am

(I'd never heard of Opus Energy before, FWIW.)

BE11:32am

Benefits of the deal. We see three key benefits from today's acquisition. (1) Opus Energy looks like a well run retail business with attractive margins in a segment that is not hugely exposed to political and media scrutiny compared to the domestic retail market. (2) The deal increases the stability of Drax's earnings and cash flows going forward. (3) There are also some opportunities for synergies related to Opus' current trading agreements.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Potential downside risks. The acquisition multiple is 10x EV/EBITDA which, in our view, does not stand out as considerably cheap. Secondly, this is the first time that the company is making a step into the SME retail market, therefore it remains to be seen whether Drax has the necessary expertise to manage this successfully. Lastly, Drax states that the combined group will be able to provide flexible and innovative energy solutions for customers, it is unclear how much of this could translate into earnings growth and shareholder return.

BE11:32am

Financial impact of Opus Energy. In 2015/16, Opus Energy generated EBITDA of £34m and EBIT of £33m. In order to fund today's acquisition Drax will enter into a new debt facility of up to £375m. Overall, on a full year basis, we estimate that the Opus acquisition would likely increase current consensus EBIT by £33m and EPS by 3p. This would add 40% and 27% to current 2017 consensus EBIT and EPS.

BE11:33am

OCGT investment. As part of today's announcement Drax will acquire four 299MW OCGT development projects from Watt Power. Two of these projects will participate in today's 2016 T-4 capacity auction and the further two will likely be entered into the 2019 T-4 auction. The initial purchase price is £18.5m, with additional payment depending upon the clearing price in future capacity market auctions.

2016 guidance. Drax has updated guidance for 2016. FY 2016 EBITDA is now expected to be at the low end of the £135-169m consensus range as a result of the CfD contract not yet being approved.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Deutsche's a bit nervous.

BE11:35am

The acquisitions should help reduce the volatility associated with Drax’s existing coal and biomass units, although the outlook for these power stations remains extremely important. In the near-term Drax should benefit from market tightness this winter and the potential for higher clearing prices from upcoming capacity auctions. However, the medium-term outlook remains challenging with 2-3 year forward power prices retrenching over the last month. The state aid decision around its fixed price biomass contract will be extremely important for the stock. The acquisition of Opus Energy is dependent on the approval of the contract and there is 100p of value at risk around the decision. Some investors have been put off investing the shares because of uncertainty around the decision, so a successful state aid decision could have a meaningful positive impact on the shares.

undefined
11:03 am
BE11:04am

FT Alphaville's daily thing.

BE11:38am

I think the research blackout came off Convatec this morning.

BE11:38am

Which we've ignored since flotation, pretty much, even though it's headed for the FTSE 100 at the end of the month.

11:38 am
ConvaTec Group PLC (CTEC:LSE): Last: 239.25, up 1.25 (+0.53%), High: 241.50, Low: 236.25, Volume: 1.93m
BE11:40am

I have initiation notes here from JPM, UBS, Merrill, Peel Hunt, Credit Suisse, Deutsche, RBC, Morgan Stanley ..........

BE11:40am

All either buy or neutral. Here's one of the former ....

11:41 am
BE11:41am

We initiate coverage of ConvaTec with a Buy rating and a 12-month price
target of 270p, implying 12% upside. ConvaTec is a global medical products
company focused on therapies for the management of chronic conditions; it
is present in the advanced wound care (33% of 2015 revenues), ostomy care
(31%), continence and critical care (21%) and infusion devices (15%)
markets. We forecast a 2017-2020E revenue CAGR of 5%, EBIT CAGR of 9%,
and EPS CAGR of 10%, with FCF growing 12% on average over the same
period. In this context, we find its current valuation undemanding:
ConvaTec trades at 16x P/E with a 6% normalized FCF yield (2017E).

BE11:41am

Goldman. Sorry about the formatting.

BE11:42am

While ConvaTec is well positioned in most markets in which it operates, its
revenue growth has lagged peers over the last four years, largely owing to
substantial share losses in ostomy (greater than 500 bp). We expect organic revenue
growth to accelerate from 4% in 2015-17E, to 5% in 2018-20E, driven by: (1)
new product launches including in the foam and negative pressure wound
markets; (2) entry into the EU continence market; and (3) improving
execution in ostomy (where we expect the pace of share losses to gradually
diminish through to 2020E). Separately, we see opportunities for ConvaTec
to substantially improve its EBIT margin, from 26.8% in 2016E to 29.8% in
2020E, driven by the company’s Margin Improvement Program (MIP). We
look to the 2016 results (February 2017) as the next catalyst for the shares.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Valuation
Our 12-month P/E-based price target of 270p assumes ConvaTec trades at
18x P/E (2017E), a 10% discount to EU Medtech; we view this as warranted
given below-average revenue and EPS growth profiles, but superior CROCI.
Key risks
A failure to turn around the performance in ostomy, lack of market share
gains and/or losses, competitive pressure, loss of long-term contracts and
execution on the MIP.

BE11:43am

And have a neutral as well, just for balance.

BE11:44am

Morgan Stanley.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

We view ConvaTec's risk-reward as compelling but believe the investment case
requires solid execution for investors to gain confidence in the company
returning to sustainable mid-single-digit organic sales growth and delivering on
margin expansion through COGS efficiencies.
1] Market Leadership: ConvaTec (CTEC) holds strong positions in all its markets,
with Advanced Wound Care (ex. NPWT & biologics) #2 in US and #3 in EU; and
Ostomy #2 in US and #3 in EU. Over the past 2 years, a strengthened leadership
team has set out a revised strategic plan, building on CTEC’s strengths.
2] Sustainable Organic Sales Growth: growth initiatives have resulted in a reacceleration of organic sales growth estimated by MS from +0% in FY13E to +1%
in FY14E to +4% in FY15E, with our FY16-19E expectations set at +4%. Permanent
return to growth in its Ostomy franchise is a key driver, helped by strengthening
its competitive position via salesforce expansion, DTC initiatives and new
products. To achieve FY16E organic sales growth guidance of+4%, CTEC needs to
show an acceleration in our momentum indicator (adjusts for tougher/easier
comps) from +7% in 1H to +10% in 2H, the strongest for more than 2 years.
Delivering on acceleration would be well received by investors; equally, a
slowdown in 2H momentum may provide a stock overhang.

BE11:44am

3] Margin Expansion – Reducing COGS: a strategic cost review using external
consultants was initiated in March 2015, pointing to a +3% point margin
improvement by 2020. Program execution began in October 2015, aimed
primarily at reducing COGS through plant rationalization, wound foam insourcing
and manufacturing improvements. FY16E EBIT margin guidance (before nonrecurring items) appears to be +26-26.2%, which implies a 2H margin of ~27.2%.
This is doable, but not necessarily a certainty, in our view.
4] Valuation – Tax Driving Debate: the sustainability of CTEC's mid-teens tax rate
is likely to be a major debate over the short to medium term. Current share price
suggests in our view investors are valuing CTEC largely on EV/EBITDA rather
than EV/NOPAT, taking a conservative tax position. At present we value CTEC on
a 2 YR forward EV/EBITDA of 13.5x (between Smith & Nephew at low-end and
Coloplast at high-end), though confidence in sustainability of the tax rate could
comfortably add +15-20% to valuation. Investors have given tax peers Sonova
and Straumann full benefit of a sustainable mid-teens tax rate, in our view.

BE11:44am

Sorry again about the formatting.

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:46am

ROTR, I've only half been paying attention to you ... Sorry ... that's what happens when you disappear off into arguing about Carney

BE11:46am

(And likewise, I guess, when I'm talking about ostomy devices.)

11:46 am
BE11:47am

But for whatever reason, this Amazon Go shop was mentioned ......

BE11:47am
BE11:47am

I'm not sure what specifically people find irksome about this idea.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

But then, I don't really understand why people find loyalty cards irksome. Or Google harvesting your browsing data to try to sell you stuff you've already bought, if I'm honest.

BE11:49am

Personally, I'm all for. I'm in favour of any future that minimises my contact with real people.

BE11:49am

As, I imagine, are real people.

11:49 am
undefined
BE11:50am

(@Roddy: one could make a convincing argument that ML has been a ten-year Turing test.)

BE11:51am

What else, then?

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Charlie Campbell at Liberum does DPL today.

BE11:51am

Beginning with the old argument: why should housebuilders trade at more than book value?

BE11:51am

11:51 am
BE11:51am

.......Or if you prefer .....

BE11:52am

BE11:52am

They should, he says, because this time is different.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Our preferred valuation measure for housebuilders is price-to-book. During the last cycle, the sector traded between 1.0x and 1.5x book value, reflecting in part the strong returns earned in that period. Going forward, the sector should trade at higher multiples than in the past, because while returns are as high, their quality is much better. With the land market remaining so benign, housebuilders are able to retain or share more of their returns and these returns are sustainably higher. We were cautious at the end of 2015 as we thought that more than 2.0x book was excessive and investors were discounting continual improvement in returns, which left little upside. The valuation is now much more compelling as shares are trading at under 1.5x book value.

BE11:53am

(@Fatdaz: that's also Plato, pretty much.)

BE11:53am

(Flaneur: A1 reference.)

11:53 am
BE11:54am

In addition to an attractive price-to-book multiple, the sector is paying out generous dividends, which give high yields. These dividends have reasonable earnings cover, but much better cash cover. We estimate the latter by adding back the cost of land, since land reinvestment is discretionary and would fall away quickly in a slowing environment. In addition, balance sheets are broadly ungeared, with only Redrow having any debt to speak of.

BE11:54am

Okay ....

BE11:54am

"With the land market remaining so benign, housebuilders are able to retain or share more of their returns and these returns are sustainably higher" ..... Hm.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

But if a cartel of housebuilders controls the available landbank ......

BE11:54am

.... and their returns are "sustainably higher" than they were previously because there's a structural shortage of houses being built on that landbank ....

BE11:55am

.... then .... oh, let's not get into this again.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

So Liberum's going for a 5% real decline in house prices next year

BE11:55am

In part because the (promised) Article 50 trigger of March 2017 falls right into spring selling season.

BE11:56am

But there's also the Government White Paper on Housing in January

11:56 am
BE11:56am

.... which might, y'know, refer in passing to that landbank hoarding thing I mentioned above.

BE11:57am

We kinda know already will give the perks to private rental schemes and smaller builders.

BE11:57am

(@Boncoeur: Indeed. I blame the limitations of this Socratic dialogue.)

11:57 am
BE11:57am

.... And might also put some pressure on the bigger builders to .... well, you know.

BE11:58am

But because it's housing -- and more specifically because important people believe in a correlation between house prices and voting preferences -- investors have no reason to worry.

BE11:58am

Worry about slowing GDP, not politics, says Liberum.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

BE11:58am

Here are the stock picks.

BE11:58am

Bellway remains a top pick in the sector as we find the valuation compelling.
We believe that volume growth should be sustained, protecting profits if
prices do fall a little as expected. The valuation is also compelling given the
expected resilience of its return on equity.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

We maintain our Buy on Berkeley in spite of the general caution around
London, as the company has secured significant forward sales to protect
prices and volumes, and has successfully added value to sites. By moving out
of central London into more affordable parts of the city and the South East,
place-making should succeed in generating value. Further, we believe the
dividend is very secure, given the strength of forward orders and long
landbank. With some of our earlier caution having proved unwarranted, and
following strong interim results, we have upgraded our 2017E EPS estimate
by 11 %.

BE11:59am

Gleeson’s unique business model gives it industry leading margins and
excellent growth prospects with limited competition. It also has the advantage
of selling in housing markets that have yet to see any meaningful house price
inflation. Valuation may be constrained by the sector, but growth is in its
hands. Our 630p target price is based on a sum-of-the-parts analysis.
We like Persimmon for its high dividend at low risk, and are confident that the
company will achieve the payments pledged because of management's
incentive scheme. Additionally, its long landbank means it could cut land
spending entirely to boost cash flows, and the strategic landbank may
continue to boost margins too. Northern areas have much better affordability
than the south, which may mean better pricing in a weaker environment.

BE11:59am

We downgrade Barratt to Sell as its lower margins make it more exposed to
downside risk, and its relatively short landbank and high land creditors mean
that it has less scope to reduce cash outflows in support of the dividend than
others in the sector.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

While Bovis now looks very cheap, we have continued to resist the
temptation to become more positive on the shares, as its margin profile
makes its earnings most geared to downside risk. The business has suffered
hiccups in better markets. We are also concerned that as the slowest builder,
it may be most at risk from any “sticks” the government could bring out in its
Housing White Paper in January.

BE12:00pm

We keep Redrow at Hold in spite of strong trading, as we believe that risk
aversion among investors may now limit appetite for investing in a
housebuilder with a degree (even though comfortable) of debt. We also think
the portfolio concentration in London is a potential risk.
We are perhaps still too cautious in leaving Taylor Wimpey as a HOLD,
especially given the high level of dividend expected. For now however, we
limit our choice among the "returners" to Persimmon.

Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 151.10, down 0.5 (-0.33%), High: 151.20, Low: 149.20, Volume: 4.27m
12:00 pm
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 466.90, down 6.8 (-1.44%), High: 468.70, Low: 460.40, Volume: 1.65m
BE12:00pm

Etc.

undefined
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Oh, look, it's midday!

BE12:02pm

But there's a request for Ashtead from .... LYO (.... narrows eyes, in the manner for Fry from Futurama.)

BE12:03pm

Q2 beat, guidance raised.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Have Peel Hunt ......

BE12:04pm

H1 profits £425m (+9% YoY at CER +25% reported) vs PHe
£410m. Sunbelt momentum continues with Q2 rental revenues
+14% (Q1 +14%) and drop through remains strong at 64%
(72% LFL). Outlook remains confident with capex guidance
increased c20%. We increase our April 2017 PBT from £750m
(cons £760m) to £790m to give EPS of 102p from 97.1p. This
reflects both currency and an underlying upgrade. Shares have
performed but continue to offer value on c12x revised April 2018
EPS given growth, quality and positioning.

BE12:04pm

Trading details: Underlying rental revenue for the Q2 period rose 33% (14% at
CER) to £784m with group EBITDA increasing 35% (15% at CER) to £417m
to give Q2 EBITDA margins of 49.4% (from 47.6%). Q2 2017 group PBT of
£242m compares to our £227m estimate and represents 14% constant currency
growth. Net debt has increased to £2,694m from the £2,348m Q1 closing
position given investment and fx moves. However, implies leverage of 1.8x
EBITDA (from 1.7x) and well within management’s 1.5-2.0x target range. ROI
dipped slightly to 18% from 19%. Importantly, the Sunbelt (92% EBITA)
revenue momentum continues with Q2 rental revenues +15% (Q1+14%) with
performance driven by volume (slight yield decline). We note that same store
volume growth is c8% (around 2x the market growth rate). Sunbelt Q2 EBITDA
margins of 51.5% (Q2 2016 49.6%) are supported by 64% drop through with
underlying same store drop through of 72%. Solid performance from A Plant
(8% EBITA) with Q2 profits rising 13% to £20.3m. We note that 17% Q2 rental
revenue growth compares favourably to peers.
Outlook Statement: is optimistic (trading upper end of expectations) and
management still sees opportunities to drive more volume across network as well
as enhance the speciality offer. Capex guidance has been increased to £1.0bn to
£1.2bn (from £0.7bn to £1.0bn). We increase our April 2017 PBT from £750m
(cons £760m) to £790m to give EPS of 102.0 from 97.1p. For FY 2018 we
increase PBT from £844m to £900m to give EPS of 117p. This partially reflects
currency as well as an underlying upgrade. Estimates are now struck at 1.30.
Valuation The shares have performed well given the combination of trading
outperformance, currency led upgrades, share buy-back (£200m programmes)
overseas earnings and attractive end markets (enhanced by recent Trump
commitment to Infrastructure). However, the rating (13x April 2018) fails to
reflect the pace of growth, potential from the Project 2021 expansion and
underlying business quality/positioning.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

... and on Imagination, also requested .....

BE12:05pm

Interims are strong on a headline basis with a beat to revenue – both licence and royalty - and EBIT, and guidance retained for FY17 with the rider of a possible FX benefit. The fly in the ointment is that the positive bits of the interims come from the less valuable parts of the business, while the core PowerVR franchise is weak. The Chairman has also announced his departure. We retain our Buy; this set of results should represent trough financials, with a stronger H2 in store and potential upside in FY18 from regained market share.

Interims look strong on a headline basis, but with underlying issues. Continuing ops revenue is ahead of plan (£64.4m versus INVe £61.0m) with both licensing revenue (£11.8m versus £10.5m) and royalty revenue (£52.5m versus £50.5m) a beat. Adjusted EBIT is some way ahead of plan (£12.2m versus £5.9m), with the cost reduction plan put through earlier in 2016 having an effect, and helped by FX. Guidance is retained for FY17 with the rider that FX may prompt an upgrade (guidance for £20m-£22m of adjusted EBIT is struck at $1.40/£; IMG bills 100% in dollars with c.60% of costs in sterling; our forecasts are struck at $1.30). Despite the year being particularly back-end loaded in H2 (always the case due to timing of royalty shipments, but particularly so in FY17 given iPhone 6s cycle weakness), the return to acceptable profit levels is welcome from the near ‘basket case’ status in H1/16.
The main fly in the ointment is that PowerVR units were expected to be weak, but are worse than expected at 191m (INVe 210m), with MIPS units helping compensate. Meanwhile, PowerVR licence is also weak, with the overall licence number being driven by Ensigma. We see both these issues as timing-related, but the fact remains that the drivers of growth in these interims are the less valuable parts of the business, plus an FX benefit. Separately, Chairman Bert Nordberg is leaving in February 2017, surprising after a relatively short period at the helm (two years); he will be replaced by Peter Hill.
Messy results, but we retain our Buy on IMG; we think the GPU IP business is worth at least 260p on the current trough financials, with potential upside in FY18E through regained Asian SoC market share (particularly Mediatek).
